bibl.title: Letter from W.W. Norman to Howard A. Kelly, October 24, 1922

div1.p: Norman details the cost of Kelly's revisions to his book.

div1.head: Letter from W.W. Norman to Howard A. Kelly, October 24, 1922
div1.opener:
The NORMAN, REMINGTON Co.
CHARLES ST. AT MULBERRY
BALTIMORE
BOOKS
STATIONERY
ENGRAVING
PRINTING
October 24, 1922
Dr. Howard A. Kelly,
1418 Eutaw Place,
City
Dear Dr. Kelly;-
div1.p:
I have consulted with our printer
over the changes required in the Walter Reed plates,
and I find that with the new copy and alterations,
over 100 pages will be affected materially by the
changes contemplated; this does not take into account
the change for the paging of the whole book from the
first 80 pages or so, nor does it include the minor
changes which are hard to gage; but the printer says
that the cost of composition, makeup and foundry lockup
would be approximately $425.00. This does not include
the price of electrotypes for which a cost of about
$1.00 a page should be calculated.

I suppose you had no idea that
the changes would involve such an expenditure. Our
arrangement of course is based upon the plates being
turned over to us as ready for printing, which is the
only practicable method that would appeal to us.

In the circumstances, therefore,
I shall await your instructions before authorizing
the printer to go ahead with the changes.
div1.closer:
Yours sincerely, W.W. Norman
THE NORMAN, REMINGTON CO. N/Mc
